Automatic controls and shutoffs are equipped with manual backups in the event of power failure or other emergencies that may cause equipment control failure.  This facility is also monitored by a SCADA (Supervisor Control And Data Acquisition) System.  The system is monitored both at the plant and at the Division's Administrative Building.

This gate is electrically operated with either key card access or manual operation from within the facility administration building when the call box is activated.  Chlorine container and chlorine feed is located in a building detached from the general administration and laboratory building.  The Chlorine building is not ventilated to the outside atmosphere and is equipped with a chlorine scrubber system.  Chlorine detectors are stationed at critical areas and connected to audible and visual alarms.  This system and its sensors is tested routinely in accordance with established manufacture protocols.

Standard Operating Procedures are continually reviewed and revised as necessary.  All policies and procedures are reviewed annually as well as for this RMP. FREDERICK COUNTY DIVISION OF Water and Sewer Utilites
NEW DESIGN ROAD WATER TREATMENT FACILITY 
850 NEW DESIGN ROAD, TUSCORORA, MARYLAND, 21790
FACILITY ID # 1000 0002 4065

SECTION I	

Frederick County Division of Water and Sewer Utilities (DWSU) owns and operates several Water and Wastewater treatment facilities in Frederick County Maryland.  This RMP covers facility #1000 0002 4065 (New Design Road Water Treatment Plant).  This facility is the largest of the Water Treatment Plants (WTP) owned and operated by Frederick County.

This facility treats about 7.0 mgd of water drawn from the Potomac River.  The New Design Road facility provides water service to 64,943 residential customers  and 1,642 commercial /industrial accounts.  Thirty thousand pounds of Chlorine (15 ton containers) is the maximum amount of Chlorine that is stored at this facility at any given time.  At this time there are no other hazardous chemicals stored at or above the reportable quantities.  There has never been a release of Chlorine at this facility that has escaped off-site.  
 
Frederick County insurance carriers make site inspections of DWSU facilities including the New Design Road WTP.  These inspections include a review of policies, procedures, training, environmental permits, contingency plans, and tier II inventories.  The last insurance inspection for this facility was completed on 6/2/2023.  Frederick County is self-insured for contractor liability insurance and a third party inspects the facility.  As a result of the last audit Frederick County Division of Fire and Rescue conducted a Hazardous Materials Pre-Emergency Response Plan in 2023.  This facility is also visited by the Frederick County Department of Fire & Rescue services annual to familiarize new staff with the facility.  


SECTION II & III

Both Release scenarios used in this RMP use a single ton container of chlorine.  With the policies, procedures, current equipment including the chlorine scrubber system, and the safet

y record of this facility, it is believed that this is the largest amount of chlorine that would be released in a single incident.  Please note that this facility has an enclosed chlorine storage area.  Chlorine sensors are connected to a chlorine scrubber system.  In the unlikely event that a chlorine leak occurs, chlorine would be contained within the room, with the air in the room being evacuated through the chlorine scrubber system. 
 
The first scenario in this RMP is a chlorine gas release that takes place over a 10 Minute period of time.  This time is the estimated time that it would take the sensors on the scrubber system to activate and alarm, personnel to respond with appropriate PPE and equipment and then begin a valve or line repair, or seal the container.  It should be noted that this facility uses vacuum regulators and in the unlikely event that a line were to break the chlorine feed system would lose vacuum and the system would shut down thus no chlorine leak through a line break.

The second scenario is a rupture of a fusible plug (relief valve) with the total contents of the container empting in eight (8) minutes.  This time frame is based on the  of the fusible plug and emptying of the entire container.


SECTION IV & V

Frederick County DWSU does not use or store flammable chemicals/materials subject to RMP reporting requirements, therefore there are no scenarios submitted for flammable materials.


SECTION VI	

The New Design Road WTP has an excellent safety record.  No accidental releases of chlorine have occurred in the 40 years plus operation of this facility.


SECTION VII & VIII

What-if & What-if/Checklists were used to update the PHA for this facility.  Review of the facility specific SOPs and Division policies and procedures are conducted annually.

All Division personnel have also taken the Incident Management course ICS 100 through FEMAs Web based training.  

Review of all policies is ongoing throughout the year.  Formal review of policies takes place once a year.  Informal review for RMP takes place annually as well.  An on-the-job training program using both job performance checklists as well as POST training is used for employee evaluation.

Contractors hired to work on projects must demonstrate that their personnel are competent to work in confined spaces, have atmospheric testing equipment that is properly calibrated and maintained, have respiratory protection and comply with other County and division safety policies.

The Division has an active Safety Committee.  This committee inspects DWSU facilities on a periodic basis and also assists in policy review.

The Division also has a Computerized Maintenance Management System (CMMS) for tracking equipment, repairs (emergency as well as routine), preventive maintenance tasks, and calibration.  This system also tracks resources (man-hours, parts, and equipment).  


SECTION IX

The Division is a Frederick County agency that works closely with other County agencies to maintain its Emergency Response preparedness.  COOP (Continuity of Operations Plan) plans have been completed along with all accompanying documents and annexes.   All Division staff have completed ICS 100 with some staff completing other Emergency Management IC classes.  Emergency Response Plans for the Division in

clude notification, evacuation and accountability requirements as well as health and safety instructions that are to be used in the event of a release.  Each facility location is required to maintain site specific SOPs for facility shutdown, evacuation, staff notification, and accountability.  The Division's ERP (Emergency Response Plan) contains a rotational on-call supervisors.  This list included home phone numbers, and cell phone numbers.  Each on-call supervisor has a two-way radio for communication as well.  The Division's radios have interoperability allowing staff to contact other county agencies including Frederick County ECC (Emergency Communication Center), highway department and other agencies that might be needed during emergencies.

Copies of any and all policies, plans, procedures and maintenance records are available for review upon request.
